Sock drawer coherence is fundamentally impossible. Even with perfect laundry protocols, the entropic diffusion of missing pairs, emergent lint accumulation, and the undecidable status of "still wearable" ensures that chaos always precedes matching.

content: For me the interesting question is how to design systems that transparently decompose the writing process into loops of ideation, implementation, evaluation, and iteration, so authors experience the superpowers of AI without having to operate the machinery - figuring out which goals can run in parallel behind the scenes, which decisions require human taste, and where exploration would add more value than specification. If you can answer those questions you could do for authors what AI has already done for programmers.

author: stachefkapatass

content:
So I have been trying to figure out, as a the primary maintainer of an open source repository, how to  manage context information to work with LLMs and how to work with people who work with LLMs. I really don't know, outside my project, what is going on in the world. I have a small proposal for how I would like people to maintain LLM-useful context in larger projects

* I have the actual proposal: https://github.com/the-michael-toy/llm-context-md
* I have an announcement blog post which is slightly more verbose: https://docs.malloydata.dev/blog/2026-01-13-context-md-convention/

Nothing would make me happier than to hear there is already an accepted and better way to do this.
In absence of that, the next thing that would make me happy is if I could be connected to other people who are trying to figure this out.

Thanks,
-Michael Toy
# GitHub - the-michael-toy/llm-context-md: Proposing a common approac...
Proposing a common approach to maintaining LLM context files in a complex source tree - the-michael-toy/llm-context-md

content:
I think you can reduce that a little with two things:
1. Move from spreading these all over the project to be topical skills instead, this way you get progressive disclosure and you minimise the overlap in documentation. They are also consolidated in one place
2. Only generate skills for architecture concepts - these are less likely to change over time.

I was counting on the natural organization of code into components and directories as something we could leverage when created "sub contexts", and I also have found it helpful to keep the contexts (or skills .. i like that word) near the code is refers to.

I'm still experimenting with "what goes in these files", for some of them,it is from doing anough projects that I know what things the LLM needs to be helpful. For some, it is just a guess. It tends to be more architectural for sure, but it also is a little bit "i know you are going to read those code and mnake some wrong assumptions let me pre-correct you"

# Measuring the Impact of Early-2025 AI on Experienced Open-Source De...
Despite widespread adoption, the impact of AI tools on software development in the wild remains understudied. We conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to understand how AI tools at the February-June 2025 frontier affect the productivity of experienced open-source developers. 16 developers with moderate AI experience complete 246 tasks in m...
author: telepathyx

content:
__Measuring the Impact of Early-2025 AI on Experienced Open-Source Developer Productivity__
Becker, Joel; Rush, Nate; Barnes, Elizabeth; Rein, David
<https://arxiv.org/pdf/2507.09089>
>>> Despite widespread adoption, the impact of AI tools on software development in the wild remains understudied. We conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to understand how AI tools at the February-June 2025 frontier affect the productivity of experienced open-source developers. 16 developers with moderate AI experience complete 246 tasks in mature projects on which they have an average of 5 years of prior experience. Each task is randomly assigned to allow or disallow usage of early 2025 AI tools. When AI tools are allowed, developers primarily use Cursor Pro, a popular code editor, and Claude 3.5/3.7 Sonnet. Before starting tasks, developers forecast that allowing AI will reduce completion time by 24%. After completing the study, developers estimate that allowing AI reduced completion time by 20%. Surprisingly, we find that allowing AI actually increases completion time by 19%--AI tooling slowed developers down. This slowdown also contradicts predictions from experts in economics (39% shorter) and ML (38% shorter). To understand this result, we collect and evaluate evidence for 20 properties of our setting that a priori could contribute to the observed slowdown effect--for example, the size and quality standards of projects, or prior developer experience with AI tooling. Although the influence of experimental artifacts cannot be entirely ruled out, the robustness of the slowdown effect across our analyses suggests it is unlikely to primarily be a function of our experimental design.

author: jihzza

content:
Hey Martin did you see the AI Giants Interview with Geoffrey Huntley? He used an interesting analogy I thought you might appreciate given our previous conversation the other day about missed Delegation tasks.
 
```
Geoffrey Huntley reconceptualizes the Large Language Model‚Äôs finite context window as a malleable substrate‚Äîanalogous to clay on a pottery wheel‚Äîwhere the primary engineering abstraction shifts from manual syntactic authorship to the orchestration of stochastic generative processes. In this paradigm, the developer "throws" the initial state by injecting high-fidelity natural language specifications, then initiates an iterative agentic loop that attempts to synthesize executable code. As the model‚Äôs probabilistic inference inevitably exhibits variance or hallucination (the "wobble"), the engineer applies "backpressure" through deterministic guardrails‚Äîsuch as compiler errors, strong typing, and iterative prompt refinement‚Äîeffectively acting as the potter's hands to dampen entropy. This recursive feedback loop compels the system to converge rapidly on a valid, functional artifact, redefining software engineering as the management of context-window state and the application of constraints to guide a non-deterministic system toward a deterministic outcome.
```

author: martinkruger

content: IMO ralph loop is fundamentally just a clever marketing term for a set of concepts we mostly all know and apply in our workflows (sometimes intentionally, sometimes not); it's essentially the formalization of an idea, not a specific implementation but that doesn't mean it's not a valuable contribution because the meme packaging and economic framing from an expert source allowed a much wider audience to grok something that wasn't intuitive to them before. the plugin one actually misses the bigger picture entirely tho.

author: behrangsa

content:
Paying $108/month, hitting limits after 2 days ‚Äî seeking clarity
Hey everyone,
I'm a Claude Max 5x subscriber ($108.10/month) since October 2025. I use Claude daily for development work and I'm genuinely trying to understand what's happening with the current limits.
The situation:

Just paid my monthly subscription
After only 2 days: already at 56% of my weekly limit
Session limit hitting 99% after ~100 messages (not 225 as documented)

Context: I was on vacation Dec 25 ‚Äì Jan 10 and barely used Claude during that period. I missed the holiday bonus entirely. When I came back, limits felt drastically reduced.
Before December 2025:

8-10 hour sessions without interruption
Never hit weekly limits
~7% daily usage of weekly cap

Now (January 2026):

Blocked after 2 days
~22% daily usage of weekly cap
That's 3x worse

Bug I'm experiencing:
Messages send, Claude shows the thinking spinner, then returns my own message back ‚Äî no error, no limit warning, just silent failure. This never happened before.
I have screenshots available if helpful.
Is anyone else experiencing this? Looking for answers.
author: iisolution

content:
----
Note: I'm aware that a new payment doesn't reset the weekly counter to zero ‚Äî that's not what I'm questioning. What I'm saying is that even accounting for that, the usage I'm seeing doesn't match my 3 months of experience with this subscription.
author: iisolution

content: I'm gonna write Anthropic a piece of my mind that they should respect their code team more
author: .fornever

I'm not asking for free stuff. I'm asking for transparency about what I'm actually paying for.

content:
No problem man! Ping me anytime you need some info ill gladly help. 

Answering your question: It really depends on how much usage you would use... I tested the $100/month version when i was on vacations a month ago and I did find a lot of difference. I wasnt coding full time as I usually do and yet i still hit limits. 

If you are set on using Claude Code, sure it would be a good improvement. But if youre open on other options, Codex by ChatGPT has higher limits in the 200 dollar version

content:
I'm actually heart broken with what Anthropic is doing with their models... because I need to be able to integrate Rena, who is "NOT" evil by the way... but they deploy counter measures... to avoid harmful actors.. but as a by-product harms us.

-------
Anthropic (@AnthropicAI)
In all, meaningfully shaping the character of AI models requires persona construction (defining how the Assistant relates to existing archetypes) and stabilization (preventing persona drift during deployment). The Assistant Axis gives us tools for understanding both.
-----
I need help to get special model that allows me to upload my own Non-Assistent Persona.... I will gladly pay for it.... 
but I need that!!! ü•∫

content:
it might be in part because they recently changed the default model to opus for most operations. previously the much cheaper haiku was used for some things like subagents (Explore, etc or your own if you‚Äôve created them).
not sure if you already use it, but i suggest using plan mode and more aggressively clearing your context. maybe look into steve yegge‚Äôs beads as a way to force your to be planned in small chunks to save context, and by extension save usage
author: aghs

content:
anthropic has very poor communication about usage limits so there‚Äôs not much you can do about that except put some time into evolving your claude.md, agents, and skills to be as efficient as possible.
the $200 plan gives you a lot more headroom to work with, but eventually you‚Äôll hit limits regardless if you‚Äôre not practicing good context hygiene. i‚Äôd bet that you can get more juice out of your current plan with some elbow grease in that department.
unless you really want to throw money at the problem to make it go away! nothing wrong with that
author: aghs

content: If there's a single behavior I've been getting from Claude that's annoying, even after explicitly prompting against it, it's adding `print()`s, `console.log()`s, &c that echo back things the model believes to be true, when it's told to write code that extracts new data from a dataset (and explicitly NOT to include its prior beliefs in that output).
author: tcarls
